subject: wsgi.Resource exception handling to not log errors
commit_message:
wsgi.Resource exception handling to not log errors

In order to not log some exceptions as errors, the
wsgi.Resource.__call__() was modified.
Instead of check if an exception is a HTTPBadRequest or a HTTPNotFound,
now all the exceptions that are not childs of HTTPError are raised
directly, without logging, translation or disguise.
If the exception is a child of HeatException, then the exception is
tranlated but not logged as an error. When this exception reaches the
Fault Wrapper Middleware it is logged as debug.
Some unused, or only use in test, exceptions were removed.

Change-Id: I105eeb74a55dcabc79cd3926dd88da0e19d1e1f1

subject: Implement account ACLs in tempauth, using the X-Account-Acl-* headers
commit_message:
Implement account ACLs in tempauth, using the X-Account-Acl-* headers

Accounts now have three headers that represent ACLs, so that auth systems
can easily represent general account access (as opposed to container-level
access).  These headers are X-Account-Acl-Read-Only, X-Account-Acl-Read-Write,
and X-Account-Acl-Admin.

Swift requires swift_owner access to set or view those headers, but puts no
conditions or expectations on their content.  Auth systems (including
tempauth) are responsible for defining the content of those headers and
taking action based on them.

This patch defines the format of the headers (in the header_to_acl_list
method and its counterpart, acl_list_to_header), and teaches tempauth to
take action based on them.  Tempauth now sets swift_owner=True if the user
is on the Admin ACL, authorizes GET/HEAD/OPTIONS requests if the user is on
any ACL, authorizes PUT/POST/DELETE requests if the user is on the admin or
read-write ACL, etc.

Core Swift is responsible for stripping out the (privileged) ACL headers
from GET responses if the user is not a swift_owner.

DocImpact: Documentation for the new ACL usage and format appears in
summary form in doc/source/overview_auth.rst, and in more detail in
swift/common/middleware/tempauth.py in the TempAuth class docstring.
I leave it to the Swift doc team to determine whether more is needed.

Change-Id: I974865ce79327d6ae4a3955b125d603914a7b936

subject: Persist and restrict access to account ACL headers
commit_message:
Persist and restrict access to account ACL headers

(X-Account-Acl-Read-Only, X-Account-Acl-Read-Write, X-Account-Acl-Admin)

Accounts now have three headers that represent ACLs, so that auth systems
can easily represent general account access (as opposed to container-level
access).  These headers are X-Account-Acl-Read-Only, X-Account-Acl-Read-Write,
and X-Account-Acl-Admin.

This patch handles the task of restricting read and write authorization on
these sensitive headers, requiring swift_owner to be True in order to read
or write them.  However, from this patch's (and core Swift's) perspective,
these headers are opaque strings.  The interpretation of the headers is
the responsibility the auth system, which will both define the format and
take action based on the content.

Read-only access is intended to indicate to the auth system that this
list of identities can read everything (except privileged headers) in
the account.  Specifically, a user with read-only account access can get
a list of containers in the account, list the contents of any container,
retrieve any object, and see the (non-privileged) headers of the
account, any container, or any object.

Read-write access is intended to indicate to the auth system that this
list of identities can read or write (or create) any container.  A user
with read-write account access can create new containers, set any
unprivileged container headers, overwrite objects, delete containers,
etc.  A read-write user can NOT set account headers (or perform any
PUT/POST/DELETE requests on the account).

Admin access is intended to indicate to the auth system that this list of
identities has "swift_owner" privileges.  A user with admin account access
can do anything the account owner can, including setting account headers
and any privileged headers -- and thus granting read-only, read-write, or
admin access to other users.

The auth system is responsible for making decisions based on these headers,
if it chooses to support their use.  Therefore the above access level
descriptions are necessarily advisory only.

subject: Implement periodic execution of benchmark scenarios
commit_message:
Implement periodic execution of benchmark scenarios

Being able to run benchmark scenarios not continuously but periodically,
setting the interval between two consecutive benchmark scenario launches,
is a crucial part of making Rally closer to real-world cloud usage scenarios.

Here we add such a capability by adding a new execution type, namely
"periodic". We also add new scenario config parameter "interval" which
enables the user to set the interval between two consecutive scenario
launches in minutes.

A sample benchmark config for periodical booting/deleting 5 servers, one
server every 2 minutes, now would look like this:

"benchmark": {
    "NovaServers.boot_and_delete_server": [
        {"args": {"flavor_id": 1,
                  "image_id": "73257560-c59b-4275-a1ec-ab140e5b9979"},
         "execution": "periodic",
         "config": {"times": 5, "period": 2,
                    "tenants": 3, "users_per_tenant": 2}}
    ]
}

subject: Run DB API tests on a given DB backend
commit_message:
Run DB API tests on a given DB backend

To proposed solution:
  - uses testrepository facilities to create a separate test
    environment for each process running a portion of test
    cases, i. e. a separate DB is created for each of test processes,
    so that they can safely be run concurrently without any data races
  - DB transactions are used to ensure that DB remains in a clean state
    after running of a test case: each test case is executed within a
    transaction which is rolled back after the test has ended.
    The 'create DB/apply migrations/run a test case/drop DB' pattern
    we currently use for running tests on SQLite in-memory DB is not an
    option, because it would take enormous amount of time to do this
    for MySQL or PostgreSQL
  - a new tox environment is added for running of DB API tests
    (as these are the only tests we want to run on DB backends other
    than SQLite in-memory DB)

To run DB API tests on a specific DB backend do:
  OS_TEST_DBAPI_ADMIN_CONNECTION=mysql://test:test@localhost/test tox -e dbapi

Note: this connection is used to create/drop test databases/users, ensure that
the specified users has appropriate rights. If OS_TEST_DBAPI_ADMIN_CONNECTION
env variable is not specified, DB API tests are run on SQLite in-memory DB.

Uses code from oslo-incubator, that hasn't been merged yet:
Ic5d3cfe8764b3c04affe79088473255c17535e54

Blueprint: db-api-tests-on-all-backends

Co-authored-By: Ilya Pekelny <ipekelny@mirantis.com>

Fix obj versioning w/non-ASCII container name

If you create a container with a non-ASCII name, and then make another
container with X-Versions-Location: first-cntner, *and* you're
serializing stuff in memcache as json (the default), when the proxy
tries to make a versioned object, it will crash.

The fix is to make sure that get_container_info() always returns strs,
not unicodes.

The long-term fix would be to get rid of simplejson entirely, as its
decoder can't make up its mind whether JSON strings should be Python
strs or unicodes, and that makes it really really easy to write bugs
like this.

objects to an older compute node. In this case, the serializer detects
the IncompatibleObjectVersion error and asks conductor to backlevel it.
This means we call into the conductor with the primitive object that we
can't handle, and basically ask it to hydrate it and call
obj_make_compatible() on our behalf and pass it back to us.

This eliminates the need for API to know whether it's talking to
an older compute and allows a newer conductor to assist older
compute nodes during upgrades to a significant degree.

subject: baremetal: cache root images if possible
commit_message:
baremetal: cache root images if possible

Previously root images are always fetched from glance for every
instance even if they use the same image. However, when file
injection is disabled (i.e. CONF.baremetal.use_file_injection is
False), the image is not changed on the compute node. So once
fetch the image, we can cache it for later reuse. It reduces the
download time and disk usage of the compute node.

Images are downloaded to a directory managed by imagechache
(e.g. /var/lib/nova/instances/_base/) rather than one for each
instance (e.g. /var/lib/nova/instances/$instance-name/).
A symbolic link is created in the instance directory instead.

called for the same target path at the same time.
